sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of educational outcome occurring in a school
message_1: Suppose a high school has 600 students and 60% of the students have enrolled in an advanced math course. What is the probability that a randomly selected student from this high school has not enrolled in an advanced math course?
message_2:
To find the probability that a randomly selected student has not enrolled in an advanced math course, we first need to determine the number of students who have not enrolled in the course.

Since 60% of the students have enrolled in the advanced math course, that means 40% have not enrolled in the course. To find the number of students who have not enrolled, we can multiply the total number of students (600) by the percentage of students who have not enrolled (40%).

600 * 0.40 = 240 students

Now, to find the probability of selecting a student who has not enrolled in the advanced math course, we can divide the number of students who have not enrolled (240) by the total number of students (600).

Probability = (Number of students who have not enrolled) / (Total number of students)
Probability = 240 / 600

Probability = 0.4 or 40%

So, the probability that a randomly selected student from this high school has not enrolled in an advanced math course is 40%.
